Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Using Three-Dimensional Confocal Rheology to Measure Shear Induced Microstructural Deformations in Colloidal Glasses
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-Technical Abstract

Complex fluids are fascinating materials with unique properties that arise from familiar constituents. For example, emulsions and foams such as salad dressing and seat cushions are comprised of simple materials such as liquid and air, yet their material properties remain topics of overwhelming interest. The goal of this Early Faculty CAREER Award is to gain a broader understanding of the glass transition by using emulsions -- a particularly interesting complex fluid. Emulsions are collections of very small liquid droplets, dispersed within another fluid, that closely mimic the behavior of atoms and molecules. However, due to their relatively large size, direct and real-time measurements of their positions and motions are obtainable in contrast to their atomic counterparts. The glass transition describes a transition in liquids that leads to their solidification when they are abruptly cooled. Rapid cooling forces the material to remain disordered while somehow becoming a solid. Remarkably, when these fluid droplets are tightly packed together, they undergo a transition where all of the droplets jam up, resulting in a material that is structurally very similar to window glass. By simultaneously deforming and imaging a glass comprised of emulsion droplets information about the mechanical properties, including the force on each droplet, can be directly measured. This information will provide key insights into the origins of the glass transition and will aid in the development of theoretical models that describe these complex materials. A major educational component initiated by the PI is the development of the Mid Atlantic Soft Matter Workshop (MASM). This workshop provides an ideal forum for researchers within the region whose interests reside at the interface of conventional disciplines. The workshop also naturally assists in the career advancement of young scientists by acquainting them with the local academic and industrial research community.

Technical Abstract

The research in this Early Faculty CAREER Award is focused on developing the unique ability to precisely control and determine the mechanical properties within soft glassy solids at the bulk and microscopic scales. A system of colloidal suspensions (emulsions) is utilized to create materials that undergo kinetic arrest similar to the glass transition in a variety of condensed materials. What makes the experimental program described in this proposal unique is the development of methods to impose precise shear stresses during direct high speed three dimensional imaging. This technology will allow the system to be externally driven and measured (rheology) while simultaneously measuring the dynamic and structural evolution of the material at the microscale. To carry out this proposed research, two well established techniques for quantifying soft materials are combined; confocal microscopy and bulk rheology. From a broader perspective, measurements of the microstructure within colloidal glasses will allow for the development of microscopic theories of amorphous materials that will provide both practical and fundamental insights. A major outreach component initiated by the PI is the development of the Mid Atlantic Soft Matter Workshop (MASM). This workshop provides an ideal forum for researchers within the region whose interests reside at the interface of conventional disciplines. The workshop also naturally assists in the career advancement of young scientists by acquainting them with the local academic and industrial research community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcomes of this support are an advancement of our fundamental and practical understanding of the relationship between microstructural properties and the flow of complex fluids. Using the support of this grant, we were able first develop a new tool that combines an imaging platform comprised of time resolved three dimensional laser scanning confocal microscopy with a mechanical testing device known as a bulkrheometer. The development of this instrument has led to a commercial product that is being marketed by the manufacturer. Moreover, we have published a paper describing how to reproduce this system.

In addition to the technological outcomes, we have made significant scientific contributions toward understanding the flow and structure of soft materials. In particular, we have investigated the flow of colloidal dispersions, emulsions, and biopolymer networks including materials such as collagen and silk. Using the funds from this grant, three graduate students have received their PhD, and two post-doctoral fellows have received support to go on to careers in industrial science. Overall, this grant contributed to the publication of five scholarly publications with two more currently in preparation.


In the main system of interest, we have utilized a system of small (1/1000th of 1 millimeter) oil droplets dispersed in water. You can think of this as being extremely precisely made mayonnaise. When these systems are produced, we choose a concentration of oil droplets that is very high making the fluid mixture into something that resembles asolid (this is known as a viscoelastic fluid). Using our combined system of precision shearing with three dimensional imaging, we are able to watch each oil droplet in view as we apply vanishingly small forces to the viscoelastic fluid. In many ways we are trying to discern how the material is put together by making it break. As we make the system flow, we measure the particle displacements and fluctuations of those displacements. In many systems that are comprised of particles that are packed closely (or Jammed) particle flucutations are often ascribed to the temperature of the system. Conventional wisdom indicates that the faster the material is made to flow, the higher the kinetic temperature. However, our measurements of the displacement fluctuations indicate that as the system flows faster, the individual particle motions within their own reference frame, become remarkably lower, indicating that the kinetic temperature is actually lower for a faster flowing system. We are now collaborating with a simulation group (Prof. Emanuela Del Gado) to investigate in very similar computer experiments, or simulations, the microscopic origins of this surprising result.


In addition to the liquid particle system of emulsions, we also investigated the flow and microstrucutre relationship in a solid particle viscoelastic material. In particular we utilized a jammed system of solid silica colloidal particles. It was shown if the particles were all the same size the system would tend to crystallize, so therefore we have chosen a bi-disperse mixture. We find that instead of staying well mixed during shearing, the system spontaneously separates into two distinct populations -- the system size segregates. This very effect is observed in dry granular materials where the size of each particle is one thousand times greater than the average size of these particles. Moreover, we find that this separation effect does not influence the linear viscoelastic modulus of the system. Remarkably, a bulk measurement of the elasticity hides the wholesale redistribution of the particle species. These results were the outcome of a PhD student supported through this grant.


This support has opened an entirely new paradigm for exploring the influence of external forces on a variety of soft materials and fluids.
